required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of an 8-week Linoleic Acid Intake in Soy Oil on Lp-PLA2 Activity in Healthy Adults

brief_summary.textblock: Self-reported healthy participants (n=150) aged 30-65 years with 18.5 kg/m^2 â‰¤ BMI < 30 kg/m^2 were randomly assigned into three groups: a low linoleic acid (LA, 18:2n-6) group (n=50) replaced 10 mL soy oil with one apple; a medium LA group (control group, n=50) maintained usual food intake; a high LA group (n=50) reduced 1/3 cup of cooked refined rice and consumed 9.9g of soy oil capsules daily as a supplement. Plasma fatty acids and lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2) activity were measured at baseline and 8 week alongside other cardiovascular disease risk factors.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and end of each 8-week diet period

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and end of each 8-week diet period
At baseline and end of each 8-week diet period
secondary_outcome.description: Lipids and lipoproteins, such as total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, triglycerides, Apo A-I, Apo B

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline and end of each 8-week diet period
At baseline and end of each 8-week diet period

arm_group.description: Individuals who replaced 10 mL soy oil with one apple
Individuals who maintained their usual food intake
Individuals who reduced 1/3 cup of cooked refined rice and consumed 9.9 g of soy oil as a supplement

intervention.description: Individuals who replaced 10 mL soy oil with one apple
Individuals who reduced 1/3 cup of cooked refined rice and consumed 9.9g (9 of 1.1g capsules, 3 capsules at every 3 meals a day) of soy oil as a supplement

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 30 to 65 years at beginning of study
- Subjects with BMI 18.5 to 30 kg/m^2
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of any medication or supplements that alter lipid metabolism.
- Presence of dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, liver disease, renal disease, chronic disease of the gastrointestinal tract, cerebrovascular disease, pancreatitis or cancer.
- Women who pregnant or lactating.
- Drug or alcohol abuse.

facility.name: Laboratory of Clinical Nutrigenetics/Nutrigenomics, Yonsei University.
